name: Topic 7: Negotiation and Industrial Relations
description: Assessment of negotiation strategies, industrial relations frameworks, council structures (JNPSNC), dispute resolution mechanisms, and relevant labour laws.

subcategories.name: A. Negotiation Principles, Processes, and Outcomes (13 Questions)
subcategories.description: Core principles, ethics (good faith), strategies (BATNA), and documentation of agreements.

questions.question: What is the primary goal of collective bargaining in the public service?
options: To create conflict between unions and management
questions.explanation: Collective bargaining seeks agreements that promote mutual understanding and balance the interests of workers and management [1].

questions.question: The principle of 'good faith' in negotiation primarily requires parties to:
options: Act honestly and fairly with a genuine willingness to reach a settlement
questions.explanation: Negotiation in good faith demands honesty, transparency, and a sincerity to reach fair outcomes.

questions.question: What is the key outcome sought from successful industrial negotiations?
questions.explanation: Successful negotiations result in mutual satisfaction and sustained industrial harmony.

questions.question: The concept of 'BATNA' in negotiation strategy refers to the:
options: Best Alternative To a Negotiated Agreement
Binding Arbitration Treaty on Negotiation Agreement
Budget Allocation for Trade Negotiations Act
questions.explanation: BATNA (Best Alternative To a Negotiated Agreement) helps negotiators understand their best fallback position if no agreement is reached [2].

questions.question: The key purpose of executing a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) after negotiation is to:
options: Summarize and formally document the agreed terms
Serve as a temporary verbal understanding
questions.explanation: An MoU records agreed positions and guides the implementation of negotiated outcomes [2].

questions.question: The process of reaching agreements on terms and conditions of employment between the employer and employee representatives is defined as:
questions.explanation: Collective bargaining is the formalized process used to determine the terms and conditions of employment for workers.

questions.question: Which of the following best defines 'industrial harmony'?
options: Peaceful and cooperative relations between employers and employees
questions.explanation: Industrial harmony refers to a state of peaceful, cooperative relations between workers and management.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a 'non-monetary issue' typically subject to civil service negotiation?
questions.explanation: Promotion and career development pathways are non-monetary negotiation issues.

questions.question: The principle of 'collective responsibility' regarding negotiated agreements means:
options: All parties must uphold and ensure the agreement is implemented
questions.explanation: Collective responsibility implies joint ownership and adherence to agreements by all negotiating parties.

questions.question: The Labour-Management Cooperation principle primarily promotes:
questions.explanation: Labour-Management Cooperation fosters dialogue and collaboration for improved productivity.

questions.question: The primary duty of a registered Trade Union in the public service is:
options: To promote members' welfare and protect employment conditions through lawful means
To restrict entry to the civil service
questions.explanation: Trade unions have the duty to represent members' welfare and protect employment conditions through lawful means.

questions.question: Effective labour relations contribute directly to which organizational outcome?
questions.explanation: Healthy labour relations improve productivity, morale, and organizational performance.

questions.question: The Labour Management Relations model fundamentally emphasizes the development of:
questions.explanation: The Labour Management Relations model emphasizes mutual respect and dialogue to foster peaceful industrial relations.

subcategories.name: B. Negotiating Bodies and Structure (12 Questions)
subcategories.description: Composition, roles, and hierarchy of the Joint National Public Service Negotiating Council (JNPSNC) and related councils.

questions.question: Which body serves as the recognized principal negotiation forum between the Government and Civil Service unions in Nigeria?
options: Joint National Public Service Negotiating Council (JNPSNC)
National Salaries, Incomes and Wages Commission
questions.explanation: The JNPSNC is the recognized forum for negotiations between Government and unions in the civil service [3].

questions.question: What does the abbreviation JNPSNC stand for?
options: Joint National Public Service Negotiating Council
Judicial National Public Sector Negotiation Committee
Job Negotiation and Pay Structure Council
questions.explanation: JNPSNC means Joint National Public Service Negotiating Council, the formal negotiation platform for the Nigerian public service [4].

questions.question: Under the NPSNC structure, which council is responsible for representing the senior staff category (typically Grade Level 07 and above)?
questions.explanation: Council I represents senior staff, typically from Grade Levels 07 and above [5].

questions.question: Which organ of the JNPSNC handles initial negotiations at the MDA level and ensures implementation of national agreements?
questions.explanation: Departmental Councils handle initial negotiations at the MDA level and implement national agreements [5].

questions.question: Under the NPSNC, quorum for National Council meetings requires representation from:
questions.explanation: Both Government and Staff Sides must be present for quorum in Council meetings.

questions.question: Which committee interprets agreements and provides policy direction between full Council sessions?
questions.explanation: The Standing Committee interprets agreements and provides policy direction between full Council sessions [6].

questions.question: Which official typically leads the Government Side delegation during National Council negotiations?
options: Head of the Civil Service of the Federation
questions.explanation: The Head of the Civil Service leads the Government's delegation in the JNPSNC [7].

questions.question: If a dispute arises within a Departmental Council that cannot be resolved locally, the accepted escalation path is to refer the matter to the:
options: To the Head of Service directly
To the National Council through the Standing Committee
To the Federal Civil Service Commission
questions.explanation: Unresolved disputes are escalated through the Standing Committee to the National Council for resolution [8].

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a recognized level of negotiation in the NPSNC structure?
questions.explanation: The NPSNC structure includes Departmental, State, and National Councils. 'Regional Council' is not a recognized level in this framework [4].

questions.question: Who chairs the Government Side in the National Council meetings?
options: Head of the Civil Service of the Federation
Secretary to the Government of the Federation
questions.explanation: The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation chairs the Government Side in the National Council meetings [7].

questions.question: The NPSNC structure exists primarily to facilitate dialogue and agreement between the Government and:
questions.explanation: The JNPSNC is the principal negotiation forum between Government and Civil Service unions [3].

questions.question: Which level of the NPSNC structure is tasked with ensuring that nationally agreed terms and conditions are implemented on the ground in individual Ministries?
questions.explanation: Departmental Councils are responsible for the local implementation of national agreements [5].

subcategories.name: C. Dispute Resolution, Industrial Relations, and Labour Law (14 Questions)
subcategories.description: Dispute mechanisms (mediation, arbitration, conciliation), legal framework (Trade Disputes Act, ILO), and industrial relations practices.

questions.question: The process of resolving a labour dispute through an independent third party whose decision is legally **binding** is known as:
questions.explanation: Arbitration involves a neutral third party making a binding decision to resolve an industrial dispute [9].

questions.question: The process of intervention by a neutral third party who assists disputing parties in reaching a **voluntary** agreement is called:
questions.explanation: Mediation helps parties reach mutual understanding without binding decisions [9].

questions.question: Which mechanism involves a neutral party assisting disputing sides to reach agreement, often the first step in statutory dispute resolution?
questions.explanation: Conciliation is a voluntary process in which a neutral party helps disputing sides reach agreement.

questions.question: Which legislation governs trade disputes and industrial relations in Nigeria?
options: Trade Disputes Act Cap T8 LFN 2004
questions.explanation: The Trade Disputes Act Cap T8 LFN 2004 provides the legal framework for dispute resolution in Nigeria's labour system [10].

questions.question: The Trade Disputes Act requires disputes to be reported within how many days after they arise to activate mandatory resolution procedures?
questions.explanation: A dispute must be reported to the Minister of Labour within 14 days to activate mediation procedures [11].

questions.question: Which official is primarily empowered to declare and mediate a trade dispute under Nigerian labour law?
questions.explanation: The Minister of Labour and Employment is responsible for declaring and mediating trade disputes.

questions.question: Industrial action, such as a strike in the Nigerian Public Service, is generally only considered lawful when:
options: All statutory dispute resolution channels have been exhausted
questions.explanation: A strike is lawful only after exhausting all legal dispute resolution mechanisms under the Trade Disputes Act.

questions.question: Which international body sets core conventions on freedom of association and collective bargaining rights for workers?
questions.explanation: The International Labour Organization (ILO) sets conventions protecting workers' rights [11].

questions.question: The ILO Convention 98 specifically deals with:
options: The right to organize and collective bargaining
questions.explanation: ILO Convention 98 guarantees workers the right to organize and engage in collective bargaining.

questions.question: The Industrial Arbitration Panel (IAP) was established to perform what function?
options: Adjudicate disputes referred by the Minister
questions.explanation: The IAP adjudicates disputes referred by the Minister of Labour for arbitration.

questions.question: The term **'check-off dues'** in union finance refers to:
options: Union dues automatically deducted from salaries by the employer
questions.explanation: Check-off dues are union contributions deducted from members' salaries and remitted to their unions by employers.

questions.question: If an employer temporarily closes down a workplace during a dispute to compel employees to accept certain terms, this industrial action is termed a:
questions.explanation: A lockout is an employer action (shutdown) during a dispute to compel employees to agree to certain terms.

questions.question: The principle of 'tripartism' in industrial relations refers to cooperation among:
questions.explanation: Tripartism is the partnership of Government, Employers, and Workers under the ILO framework.

questions.question: What is the principle that underpins fair labour practices, according to the ILO framework?
questions.explanation: Freedom of association ensures workers can organize and bargain collectively [11].
